entry.title: Some vocabularies and beautiful sentences from the book thief
entry.content: A snowball in the face is surely the perfect beginning to a lasting friendship. 直撞向脸蛋的雪球应当是一段持久友谊最完美的开始。 He caught his son’s ear between his thumb and forefinger. 他用两只手指拎着他儿子的耳朵 How does a book thief end up kneeling and howling and flanked by a man-made heap of ridiculous, greasy, cooked-up rubble? 为什么偷书贼最终跪在地上嚎哭，身边堆积着人为造成的可笑肮脏的废墟？ I hang suspended, until a septic truth bleeds toward clarity. 我似是在空中悬浮着，直到丑陋的真相逐渐变得清晰 They’re the ones I can’t stand to look at, although on many occasions I still fail. I deliberately seek out the colors to keep my mind off them, but now and then, I witness the ones who are left behind, crumbling among the jigsaw puzzle of realization, despair, and surprise. They have punctured hearts. They have beaten lungs. 他们是虽然我极力避免，却总是忍不住观察的一群人。 我精心去寻找各种颜色，使我不再注意他们。但是有时我看见被遗弃的他们，在由认知、绝望和惊奇构成的拼图中崩溃了。他们的心早已千疮百孔 It’s the story of one of those perpetual survivors—an expert at being left behind. 这是一个关于一个永远的幸存者的故事——拥有丰富的被遗弃经历 Rudy Steiner—the boy next door who was obsessed with the black American athlete Jesse Owens. 鲁迪—-一个疯狂迷恋美国运动员欧文斯的邻家男孩 Snowflakes of ash fell so lovelily you were tempted to stretch out your tongue to catch them, taste them. Only, they would have scorched your lips. They would have cooked your mouth. Clearly, I see it. 片片灰屑，坠落得如此迷人。你可能急切地想伸出舌头尝尝它们的味道，只是这些碎屑一定会灼伤你的嘴唇，烫熟你的嘴巴. Earlier, kids had been playing hopscotch there, on the street that looked like oil-stained pages. When I arrived, I could still hear the echoes. The feet tapping the road. The children-voices laughing, and the smiles like salt, but decaying fast. Then, bombs. This time, everything was too late. The sirens. The cuckoo shrieks in the radio. 早些时候，孩童们还在油渍浸满的街上跳房子。当我抵达时，脚步声，笑声依然清晰可见，可就像盐一般，它们马上就融化了。紧接着的炸弹，布谷鸟一般嚎叫的警报器，太迟了， They fall on top of each other. The scribbled signature black, onto the blinding global white, onto the thick soupy red. 他们互相重叠，潦草签名般的黑色，与炫目的白茫茫一整片，似汤一般浓稠的血色交叠着 Was it fate? Misfortune? Is that what glued them down like that? 是命运吗？是不幸吗? 是什么让他们变成如今这样？ As the crowd arrived in full, things, of course, had changed. The horizon was beginning to charcoal. What was left of the blackness above was nothing now but a scribble, and disappearing fast. 当人群全部抵达，所有事都变了 You see, to me, for just a moment, despite all of the colors that touch and grapple with what I see in this world, I will often catch an eclipse when a human dies. I’ve seen millions of them. I’ve seen more eclipses than I care to remember. it was only a matter of time before the charcoaled Owens drew clear and streaked away. A suddenness found its way onto his lips then, which were a corroded brown color and peeling, like old paint. In desperate need of redoing. Each half was glowing, and beating under all that white. He didn’t care that others made noises about the new girl’s stupidity. He was there for her at the beginning, and he would be there later on, when Liesel’s frustration boiled over. But he wouldn’t do it for free. THE ONLY THING WORSE THANA BOY WHO HATES YOUA boy who loves you. In fact, you could say that Rosa Hubermann had a face decorated with constant fury. In the dream, she was attending a rally at which he spoke, looking at the skull-colored part in his hair and the perfect square of his mustache. It felt as though the whole globe was dressed in snow. Like it had pulled it on, the way you pull on a sweater. Next to the train line, footprints were sunken to their shins. Trees wore blankets of ice. As you might expect, someone had died. It is one of the small legion I carry, each one extraordinary in its own right. Each one an attempt— an immense leap of an attempt—to prove to me that you, and your human existence, are worth it. It was a small concoction of disjointed hand movements, muffled sentences, and mute, self-conscious turns. Next is a signature black, to show the poles of my versatility, if you like. It was the darkest moment before the dawn. On the other was the squat shape of Rosa Hubermann, who looked like a small wardrobe with a coat thrown over it. People have defining moments, I suppose, especially when they’re children. For some it’s a Jesse Owens incident. For others it’s a moment of bed-wetting hysteria: People on the street stood and watched, some with straight-armed salutes, others with hands that burned from applause. Some kept faces that were contorted by pride and rally like Frau Diller, and then there were the scatterings of odd men out, like Alex Steiner, who stood like a human-shaped block of wood, clapping slow and dutiful. Perhaps ten meters to my left, the pale, empty-stomached girl was standing She was listening contentedly to the torrent of words spilling from his mouth. His sentences glowed in the light. Somewhere, far down, there was an itch in his heart, but he made it a point not to scratch it. He was afraid of what might come leaking out. That was how the creases were made in the cardboard texture of her complexion. The book thief had struck for the first time—the beginning of an illustrious career. The trouble is, who could ever replace me? Who could step in while I take a break in your stock-standard resort-style vacation destination, whether it be tropical or of the ski trip variety? The world was sagging now, under the weight of all that snow. “Because you shouldn’t want to be like black people or Jewish people or anyone who is . . . not us.” they sat in the rising pool of darkness the boy’s spirit was soft and cold, like ice cream. He started melting in my arms. Then warming up completely see a long list of colors, but it’s the three in which I saw her in the flesh that resonate the most. Yes, the sky was now a devastating, home-cooked red. Whoever named Himmel Street certainly had a healthy sense of irony. When the train pulled into the Bahnhof in Munich, the passengers slid out as if from a torn package. There were people of every stature, but among them, the poor were the most easily recognized. The impoverished always try to keep moving, as if relocating might help. They ignore the reality that a new version of the same old problem will be waiting at the end of the trip—the relative you cringe to kiss. When she came to write her story, she would wonder exactly when the books and the words started to mean not just something, but everything. Was it when she first set eyes on the room with shelves and shelves of them? Or when Max Vandenburg arrived on Himmel Street carrying handfuls of suffering and Hitler’s Mein Kampf ? Was it reading in the shelters? The last parade to Dachau? Was it The Word Shaker? Perhaps there would never be a precise answer as to when and where it occurred. They were made of kindness, and silver. Like soft silver, melting. Liesel, upon seeing those eyes, understood that Hans Hubermann was worth a lot. There was an intense spurt of coughing. Almost an inspired spurt.And soon after—nothing. There was a distinct waddle to her walk. Almost cute, if it wasn’t for her face, which was like creased-up cardboard and annoyed, as if she was merely tolerating all of it. There most definitely was value in him, and it did not go unnoticed by Liesel Meminger. (The human child—so much cannier at times than the stupefyingly ponderous adult.)

entry.title: The Chian -US trade dispute ---- An ocean apart
entry.content: Although hopes of a deal buoy up stock markets, a chasm remainsBackground information Last year, when American officials visited Beijing for trade negotiations, they spent more time fighting among themselves than against China. They could not agree on who should lead the talks or what their goal should be. Seeing such amateurism, their Chinese interlocutors reckoned that they had little to worry about. main function: demonstrate the internal conflicts in America of previous negotiation between America and China. ( May be ready for a comparison) Vocabulary： amateurism ：amateur(业余的) + ism [as a hobby rather than for vocation] interlocutors : inter+locut–loqui(to talk)+or[a middleman who speak on behalf of an organization] reckon: guess or think Many of the same Americans have been back in Beijing for more talks in recent days. But this time they had an undisputed leader—Robert Lighthizer, the hard-nosed United States Trade Representative—and a clear set of demands. Their Chinese counterparts, having seen President Donald Trump’s zeal for tariffs, knew that they had something to worry about after all. main function : reveal the current circumstances between America and China V&S: undisputed：something is widely accepted as being true. To dispute is to argue, and when you add the prefix un-, “not,” you get something that can’t be argued with. hard-nosed: being tough, stubborn, or uncompromising zeal: eagerness and ardent interest in pursuit of something America has set a deadline of March 1st for an agreement. If it is missed, tariffs on $200bn-worth of imports from China are due to rise from 10% to 25%, inflicting more pain on a slowing Chinese economy. That would invite a sharper backlash from China. Its ability to direct firms to shift purchases to other countries has already hurt American exporters (see chart). Chinese officials resent the deadline but it has focused minds. The latest talks, which began on February 11th and were due to end on February 15th, are the third round this year. main function: V&S: the third around negotiation because of their rivalry to each other inflict : to cause (something unpleasant) to be endured invite: to increase the likelihood of e.g. invite trouble backlash: a strong adverse reaction (as to a recent political or social development) focus minds : be absorbed in All this has fed expectations that the two sides could soon make peace—or at least extend their truce. Mr Trump told reporters that he might let the deadline slide if a good deal is within reach. Another meeting between Mr Trump and Xi Jinping, China’s president, is under discussion. Investors have taken heart. American and Chinese stock markets have both risen by about 10% this year. main function: two sides could make peace V&S : two sides could make peace truce:a respite especially from a disagreeable or painful state or action let the deadline slide: extend（defer ，adjourn） the deadline take heart: gain courage The outlines of a deal have been in view for a while. China would probably promise to buy lots of goods from America, from soya beans to natural gas, and allow foreign companies more access to its economy. America would cut tariffs and perhaps promise to remain open to Chinese investors, as long as they are not part of a state-backed assault on sensitive technology. main function: the imagination of specific contents of outlines V$S: have been in view for a while a state-backed assault on sensitive technology Yet when negotiators get into the details, problems surface. After many frustrating years waiting for China to open its markets, the Americans suspect that its pledges will be empty. The Chinese suspect that America is motivated by a desire not for fair trade but for thwarting a new rival. main function: they are skeptical to each other V&S pledge: promises thwart: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of Two key outstanding questions are thus how to measure whether China lives up to its word, and what America can do if it fails. Scott Kennedy of the Centre for Strategic and International Studies in Washington says changes should be measured by China’s economic outcomes, not by its stated policies. The government has, for instance, agreed to scrap rules that foreign firms must find local partners to make cars in China. The test, says Mr Kennedy, ought to be whether foreign carmakers actually do set up wholly owned firms in China and operate them successfully. main function: two measurements of the realization degree of Chinese promises V&S: live up to its words : fulfill their pledges scrap : dispose of (something useless or old) And if it is judged that China is not keeping its promises? One option is to submit disputes to neutral arbitration. Mr Lighthizer is said to dislike this idea. Another is to give America the right to slap tariffs unilaterally on Chinese goods—which China is understandably loth to accept. Even as the trade war seems to be cooling, a chasm still lies between the combatants. main function: identify a chasm still lies between combatants , especially when China does not live up to its promises. V&S: disputes: controversies arbitration: The person in charge of the arbitration acts like an official referee, helping both sides come to an agreement. slap tariffs: levy customs unilaterally: Doing something unilaterally means it’s done without the agreement or participation of other people it might affect. loth: unwilling chasm: A chasm is a deep divide, either literal or figurative, such as a giant chasm in an ice cap or the growing chasm between two friends who haven’t spoken in a long time combatant: Someone who fights, especially in a war, is a combatant. Sometimes entire countries are described as combatants during military conflicts. Translation 尽管达成协议的希望推高了股市，但分歧依然深刻,去年，美国官员到访北京进行贸易谈判时，他们花在内部争论上的时间比和中国官员谈判还要多。他们无法就谁应该领导谈判和谈判的目标是什么达成一致。看到这样业余的表现，他们的中国谈判对手认为自己没有什么好担忧的。 近日，这些美国官员中的很多人重返北京，展开更多磋商。但这一次他们有了一位无可争议的领导——固执的美国贸易代表罗伯特·莱特希泽（Robert Lighthizer），也有了一系列清晰的诉求。他们的中国谈判对手见识到了特朗普对关税的狂热，明白自己终究还是要有所担忧。 美国把 3 月 1 日定为达成协议的最后期限。如果不能如期达成，便将把价值 2000 亿美元的中国商品的关税从 10% 提升至 25%，这会让已经放缓的中国经济雪上加霜。而这将促使中国发起更激烈的反击。它可以直接指挥企业转向其他国家采购，美国的出口商已经因此受损（见图表）。中国官员对这一期限心怀不满，但明确的期限也让双方集中了注意力。最近一次谈判从 2 月 11 日持续到 15 日，是今年的第三轮谈判。 所有这些都让人预期双方可能很快会达成和解，或者至少会延长休战期。特朗普对记者说，如果令人满意的协议近在咫尺，他可能不会死盯着最后期限。双方正在讨论特朗普和习近平再进行一次会谈。投资者已受到鼓舞。今年美国和中国股市都上涨了 10% 左右。 协议生成雏形已有一段时日。中国可能将承诺购买从大豆到天然气的大量美国产品，并允许外国公司更多地参与本国经济。美国将削减关税，并可能承诺对中国投资者保持开放，只要他们不会在政府的支持下对敏感技术出手。 但当谈判双方深入细节时，问题就会出现。经过多年空等中国开放市场，美方怀疑中国的承诺只是空话。中方则怀疑美国的目的并非公平贸易，而是要打压一个新对手。 因此，两个有待解决的关键问题就是如何衡量中国是否兑现了承诺，以及若未兑现美国能怎么做。华盛顿战略与国际研究中心的斯科特·肯尼迪（Scott Kennedy）说，应该用中国的经济成果而不是它提出了怎样的政策来衡量改变。例如，中国政府已经同意废除外国公司必须和本地企业合资才能在中国制造汽车的规定。那么，肯尼迪说，衡量方法就是看外国汽车公司是否确实在中国建立了全资公司并成功经营。 而如果认定中国没有遵守承诺呢？一种方法是将争端提交中立机构仲裁。据说莱特希泽不喜欢这种做法。另一个方法是让美国有权单方面对中国商品征收关税——中国自然不乐意接受。就在贸易战看似降温之际，交战双方之间仍然横亘着一道鸿沟。

entry.title: How to deal with difficult sentences?
entry.content: Main classification复杂修饰成分 从句（主语，宾语，定语，状语，同位语） 介词短语修饰 分词修饰 不定式修饰 定语从句 e.g. The methods that a company devices to perpetuate itself come into being to preserve aspects of the cultural legacy that that community perceives as essential ​ Strategy: 先找主谓宾（主语为：The methods，谓语为 come into being 而后是一个以不定式to 引导表示目的的状语） 主语从句 e.g.That each large firm will act with consideration of its own needs and thus avoid selling its products for more than its competitors charge is commonly recognized by advocates of free-market economic theories ​ Strategy: 句首出现了以that 引导的长从句为主语 ​ 把长从句理解成一个名词作主语，中文翻译时，句尾加上“这一点” 宾语从句 e.g. The historian Frederick wrote in the 1890’s that the agrarian discontent that had been developing steadily in the united states since about 1870 had been precepted by the closing of the internal frontier — that is , the depletion of available new land needed for further expansion of the American farming system. ​ Strategy: 注意that 按顺序读即可 长状语 e.g. The appreciation of traditional oral American Indian literature has been limited, hampered by poor translations and by the difficulty, even in the rare culturally sensitive and aesthetically satisfying translation, of completely conveying the original’s verse structure, tone, and syntax. ​ ​ Strategy: 状语部分分割了结构 the difficulty of 的结构 ​ 状语能表示时间地点方式程度原因结果背景，且出现在句子任意位置 层层修饰 e.g. A very specialized feeding adaptation in zooplankton is that of the tadpole like appendicular Ian who lives in a walnut-sized or smaller balloon of mucus equipped with filters that capture and concentrate phytoplankton ​ Strategy: 从who 开始对宾语的三层修饰 ​ 并列成分 e.g They were fighting, albeit discreetly, to open the intellectual world to the new science and to liberate intellectual life from ecclesiastical philosophy and they envisioned their work as contributing to the growth , not of philosophy but of research in mathematics and physics ​ Strategy:第一个and连接两个并列的不定式，第二个and 连接两个完整的句子 多重否定 大段插入语及同位语 普通插入 e.g. Moreover, I can feel strong emotions in response to objections of art that are interpretations, rather than representations, of reality. ​ Strategy: in response to 引导的，修饰emotion 的介词结构中，介词宾语被由that引导的定语从句所修饰，而定语从句中的表语被插入语 rather than representation 所分割 ​ 删除成对逗号，再反读句意。 短语被分割 e.g. Such variation in size, shape, chemistry, conduction speed, excitation threshold, and the like as had been demonstrated in nerve cells remained negligible in significance for any possible correlation with the manifold dimensions of mental experience e.g. under the force of this view, it was perhaps inevitable that the art of rhetoric should pass from the status of being regarded as of questionable worth (because although it might be both a source of pleasure and a means to urge people to right action , it might also be a means to distort truth and a source of misguided action) to the status of being wholly condemned. ​ Strategy: such as , so that, too…to, more than. From A to B, between A and B 为避免头重脚轻而倒转至句末 e.g. The sex ratio will be favored which maximize the number of descendants an individual will have and hence the number of gene copies transmitted. ​ Strategy: 由于主语 the sex ratio 之后的以which引导的定语从句过长，原文将长长的定语从句倒装于谓语will be favoured 之前，避免头重脚轻之感 e.g. Black fiction surveys a wide variety of novels, bringing to our attention In the process some fascinating and little-known works like James Weldon Johnson’s Autobiography of an Ex–Colored man. ​ Strategy: bring 后接的长宾语被放置到句末 及物动词加介词 e.g. Yet Walzer’s argument, however deficient, does point to one of the most serious weakness of capitalism—–namely, that it brings to predominant positions in a society people who, no matter how legitimately they have earned their material rewards, often lack those other qualities that evoke affection or admiration ​ Strategy: throw over, insert into, import into, infer from, establish for, advocate as 常易被倒装 ​ bring A to B ——- bring B A 及物动词加副词 e.g. Frank, however, predicted that women would be liberated from the ‘social, legal, and economic subordination ‘ of the family by technological developments that made possible the recruitment of the whole female into public industry. ​ Strategy: possible 被倒装到了前面 省略 e.g. The sex ratio will be favored which maximize the number of descendants（that） an individual will have and hence(maximizes) the number of gene copies transmitted. Strategy: 在maximize 的第一个宾语 the number of descendants an individual will have 中，an individual will have是修饰descendants的定语从句，故省略引导词that. ​ 第二个 the number of 之前省略了同之前一样的maximize 重复的成分 e.g. The correlation of carbon dioxide with temperature, of course, does not establish whether changes in atmospheric composition caused the warming and cooling trends or were caused by them Strategy: them 取代了 the warming and cooling trends 让步转折的省略e.g. Strategy: 让步和转折的词汇，同一个句子只能出现一次 ​ 阅读时，有意识地补全让步和转折的语气，避免句子奇长 定语从句引导词的省略 e.g. Because the potential hazards(that) pollen grans are subject to as they are transported over long distance //are enormous,…….. Strategy:修饰主语 potential hazards 的定语从句引导词that被省略了 定语从句中的引导词与系动词同时省略，变成后置定语 e.g. qualities such as ‘the capacity for hard work ‘ essential in producing wealth Strategy: 原：名词+定语从句引导词+形容词+介词结构 ​ 现： 名词+形容词+介词结构 ​ 因有介词结构，连带形容词一起后置

entry.title: The forth day of word 10000
entry.content: Today analgestic anninilate annotate antagonize anticlimax aphorism aquatic arboretum analgesic [ˌænəlˈdʒi:zik] n/adj 止痛剂，止痛的 [GRE] pain killer <algia-表示疼痛pain, a=an-(not)否定+algia“不疼”> nostalgia [nɔˈstældʒə] n 思乡，怀旧 severe home sick <nost-nest“想到自己的家心里就疼”或者用谐音“那是他家”> neuralgia [njuˈrældʒə US nu-] n 神经疼 ​ annihilate [əˈnaiəleit] vt消灭，歼灭 注意h不发音 <-ate 不看因为只是动词后缀，nihil=nothing虚无， n与否定有关 ， “没有山”所以是虚无的> nihilism [ˈnaiəlizəm] n 虚无主义<-ism表示主义> nihilist虚无主义者（尼采，叔本华） null [nʌl] adj 值为零的，无效的，空zero <n表示加强> nullify [ˈnʌlifai] v 废除 annul[əˈnʌl] v 使无效，废除 <加强为零> ​ rescind[riˈsind]废除，取消 （annul和rescind 都表示官方的废除，取消） annual [ˈænjuəl] adj 一年一度的 annotate [ˈænəteit] v注释，评注 annotation n注释 <来自note记录=to mark，an表示“加强标记”→注释> notion [ˈnəuʃən] n 见解想法（一个人的idea,观点，见解） notation [nəuˈteiʃən] n符号 denotation [ˌdi:nəuˈteiʃən] n 意义 <de:①.向下 ②.off ③.to加强（大多数）> connotation [ˌkɔnəˈteiʃən] n 隐义，内在含义inside meaning <符号放在一起，意思不一样了> notorious [nəuˈtɔ:riəs] adj 臭名昭著的同flagrant <起个外号是个明显的劣迹> antagonize [ænˈtægənaiz] vt 敌对，对抗~ sb\ sth 同 be against <anta-等于anti- 表示相反，ag=act行动，做相反的行动> antagonist [ænˈtægənist]n敌手，对手,反派rival, contestant <anti-+ag-> protagonist[prəuˈtægənist]n小说，戏剧中的主人公 <在前面行动的人> 各种角色： leading role主角 supporting role\actor配角 extra 临时演员，跑龙套的人 stand-in替身 <站在戏里却不是自己> agitate [ˈædʒiteit] v 激起，煽动，和soothe 相反 <it表示走，ag表示行动，“走，去行动”→煽动> cogitate [ˈkɔdʒiteit] v仔细思考consider carefully <一起行动> ~ on sth cogent [ˈkəudʒənt] adj 同persuasive有说服力的 <能让人一起行动的> 用法： ~ evidence exigent [ˈeksɪdʒənt, ˈegzɪ-] adj 紧急的，急迫的,同urgent <紧急出动> agile [ˈædʒail] adj 灵敏的，敏捷 <-ile如果作为形容词后缀表示易于…的,如fragile表示易碎的，“易于行动的”→灵敏的 > anticlimax [ˌæntɪˈklaɪmæks] n突降法，虎头蛇尾，令人扫兴的[SAT] <anti-against, climax n 高潮(小说，戏剧)，心情突然从高潮跌落下来了> antic [ˈæntik] adj 反常的，古怪的，滑稽的 <“反的”> antiseptic [ˌæntiˈseptik] adj/n 防腐的，防腐剂 <septic-腐烂的，腐臭的，“七月的东西易腐烂”> 罗马从3月March开始计数，一年共有十个月sep-7 decade十**, Dec-10,december decade [ˈdekeid] n 十年 septwolves 七匹狼 antithesis [ænˈtiθisis, ænˈtiθəsis] n 对立上的观点 aphorism [ˈæfərizəm] n 格言，谚语,同motto 座右铭 [GRE] <ism表示一种主义，一种精神，没有用，a表示加强，pho=-fer-表示carry,如confer和defer，一句带来精神的话 > sophism [ˈsɔfizəm] n诡辩术，似是而非的理论 <soph=wisdom> philosophy [fiˈlɔsəfi] n 哲学<philo-爱，sophy-智慧,爱智慧即为哲学> sophisticated [səˈfistikeitid] adj 精明的，老于世故的，（仪器）精密复杂的<一个人智慧过多> aquatic[əˈkwætik] adj 水生的，水栖的 to live in the water <aqua=water> aquarium [əˈkweəriəm] n水族馆 <-um表示地点> Aquarius[əˈkweəriəs US əˈkwer-]水瓶座 What’s your sign? 你是什么星座的？ opaque [əuˈpeik] adj 不透明的，晦涩的，难懂的 not transparent <op=ob①加强 ②相反opposite “不像水那样”→不透明> transparent [trænsˈpeərənt] a 透明的 aquifer[‘ækwəfə] n 含水层 <fer=carry “搬水，携带水”→含水层> aqueous [ˈeɪkwiəs] adj 含水的 containing water arboretum [ˌɑ:bəˈri:təm] n 树木园，植物园[GRE/SAT] <-um地点 arbor-tree表示树，和(h)erb同源> herbal tea （王老吉上有） harbor [ˈhɑ:bə] n 港口 <harbor港口挡风雨， arbor树荫挡太阳> arbor [ˈɑ:bə] n 树阴处 the shadow of a tree arboreal [ɑ:ˈbɔ:riəl] adj 树栖的，树生的 [GRE] <“树+的”> arboriculture[‘ɑ:bəri,kʌltʃə] n 树木养殖业 <culture表示“……养殖业”> forestry [ˈfɔrɪstri US ˈfɔː-, ˈfɑː-] n 林业

entry.title: The third day of word 10000
entry.content: alcove [ˈælkəuv] n 凹室，壁橱，神龛[GRE] <cove-cave，al-加强，“挖一个洞”> 各种cave: cavity [ˈkæviti] n 小洞，洞穴；体内的腔 <词根+ity > cavern [ˈkævən] n 大洞穴，大山洞，大溶洞 <中间有一个cave> excavate [ˈekskəveit] v 挖掘，出土 <ex-向外,从cave里面弄出来> dig out concave [ˌkɔnˈkeiv] a 凹陷的 <洞的特征，cave是往里凹的> convex [ˌkɔnˈveks] a 凸起的 allay [əˈlei] vt 减轻，减少(情感) ，同abate <al-加强,加强躺，多躺一会 同源：alleviate, levi=①上升，如elevator②表示轻(能被人举起来的) 如maglev train 磁悬浮列车 > allay your fear\anxiety levity [ˈleviti]n 轻浮的（指人的性格特征），草率的 blithe [反]gravity稳重 levy [ˈlevi] v征收(税等) n.征税，税款<国家负担减轻> levy tax on ; levy import duty\tariff on rescind [riˈsind] v废除，取消 ~ the tax <sci联想scissors 剪掉，剪断,加强剪断→废除> waylay [weɪˈleɪ] v潜伏，伏击<埋伏\躺在路边> lurk slay [slei] v 暗杀 kill 变化： slew slain ​ <sl和slip有关，被杀死以后滑到的动作,或用谐音“死嘞”> flay [flei] v 去皮，剥皮；严厉批评 ​ flay a dog flay the animal（get rid off the skin ） belay [bɪˈleɪ] v 拴住，绑住 ~ the horse to the tree <be-加强> ​ tie [tai] v 同belay ​ bind [baind] v 把人绑树上的那种绑 underlay [ˈʌndəleɪ US -ər-] v垫起，铺在底下 outlay [ˈautlei] n 花费、花销(尤指特定目的的花费) <放出去的钱> 与“杀死”有关： massacre[ˈmæsəkə] v大屠杀 <mass-大量,acre英亩,在一亩地中杀死> assassinate [əˈsæsineit] v 刺杀 <在ass后面给两刀> lynch [lintʃ] v 处以私刑<读音很像凌迟> strangle [ˈstræŋgl] v 吊死，扼死 <来自string> smother [ˈsmʌðə] v闷死，使窒息 make sb airless ​ <来自smoke“死妈”，联想武则天闷死女儿> aloof [əˈlu:f]adj冷淡的，孤零的 <100+far“离我一百米远”远离，冷淡> a作为表状态的组词结构 aground [əˈgraund] adj搁浅的 The ship went ~ afoot [əˈfut] adj①.徒步的②.在进行中的 The project is ~ alight [əˈlait] adj，v 燃烧 <发着光的，着火> The car is alight=The car is burning alight from=get off aghast [əˈgɑ:st] adj可怕的 <ghost,有鬼很可怕> afresh [əˈfreʃ] adv重新，又一次 do sth again from the beginning =again akin [əˈkin] adj 同族的，同源的 <来自kin-relative，同亲戚的，与皇帝king沾亲带故 > aloof 同义词： frigid [ˈfridʒid] adj 冷漠的，冷的，冷淡的，性冷淡的, freeze冷冻 ​ <fridge冰箱> It’s ~ today. standoffish [stændˈɔfiʃ] adj（情感上）冷淡<stand-off-ish“站远点”> apathetic [ˌæpəˈθetik] adj冷漠的 <a-表否定， path-pass情感，如passion激情> apathy [ˈæpəθi] n 无情,冷漠 sympathy [ˈsimpəθi] n 同情 antipathy [ænˈtipəθi] n 反感 <anti-表示反，“反+感”> ​ antibody [ˈæntiˌbɔdi] n 抗体 empathy [ˈempəθi] n 情感,同情 =sympathy <em, en表加强> compassion [kəmˈpæʃən] n 同情，事假 ​ <com一起，pass表示情感一起给你情感> ​ compassionate leave事假, sick leave 病假 *“100系列”: loot [lu:t] v 掠夺，洗劫，战利品 <100个人一起踢> loom [lu:m] n织布机，梭子 <100米> v appear 隐隐约约地耸现loom up; loom so large(社会问题等的出现)日益突出，尤为重要，表现正反向都可以（写作中可以使用，如sth is looming so large表示某个问题逐渐突出） loop[lu:p]n环，圈 ​ <100people站成一个圈> clockwise\counterclockwise loop ​ altruism [ˈæltruizəm] n 利他主义<alter-表示其他> altruist [ˌæltruˈistik] n 利他主义者 egoism [ˈiːgəuɪzəm, ˈeg- US -gou-] n 利己主义 <ego-自己 my ego是myself , egocentric以自我为中心的> My ego is a worker 注意不能说myself is a worker. ​ amalgam [əˈmælgəm] n 混合物,汞合金[GRE] <两个AM合并成一个LG公司 > amalgamate [əˈmælgəmeit] v 混合；合并（combine） 反义词：separate eg: Two firms ~ into one cooperation coalesce [ˌkəuəˈles] v 合并 <co-一起表示合并,al-all，esce-逐渐“逐渐所有都到一起”> mingle [ˈmiŋgəl] v 交织，混合（物体或情感） <le表示动词直接去掉,ming=mix> mingle excitement with anxiety ambush [ˈæmbuʃ] v 潜伏 <am-=im- 藏在（bush）灌木丛里面> 回忆：waylay，lurk lush [lʌʃ] adj 繁茂的，茂盛的 <l-拉屎繁茂树木> luxury [ˈlʌkʃəri] n 奢华，多的样子 plush [plʌʃ] adj 豪华的 <拼音p想成漂亮的> hush [hʌʃ] v,n安静，小声 ，hush-hush嘘 <h-呼吸，安静> gush [gʌʃ] adj 液体的涌出 <gu拼音“鼓出”> gusher 喷油井 Summary:“鼓出就是涌出，呼吸就是安静，漂亮才能豪华，拉屎繁茂树木” amorous [ˈæmərəs] adj 多情的，恋爱的 <am-amour=love> amiable [ˈeimiəbəl] adj 友好的，亲切和蔼 <能让人爱，也能爱别人的> amicable [ˈæmikəbəl] adj 指人同上，指集体是和睦友好的 amity [ˈæmiti] n 和睦<联想爱慕> enmity [ˈenmiti] n 敌意 < en联想enemy > pamper [ˈpæmpə] v 溺爱 <单音节p与手掌palm有关，捧在手里去爱> Pampers帮宝适 peep [pi:p] v 偷看 <两个手放两眼边上> enamor[i’næmə] v 迷恋，着迷 be enamored of迷恋，特别喜爱 amphibian [æmˈfibiən] adj 两栖的 <bio=生命,ambi \ amphi:①.around②.both > ambition [æmˈbiʃən] n 野心 <四处走的人有野心> amphitheater [ˈæmfɪˌθɪətə US -ər] n 斗兽场，环形剧场 ​ <amphi-取环形的意思，环形的剧院> ambiguous [æmˈbigjuəs] adj 模棱两可的 not clear ​ <ambi-二,gu拼音“估”，估计出来两个答案，很模棱两可 > ambivalent [æmˈbivələnt] adj 内心矛盾的，纠结的 ​ <ambi-表示二，内心两种价值,val=value价值观> ambidextrous [ˌæmbiˈdekstrəs] adj 双手灵巧的，双手善用的 <dextr=right，右面，有两只右手，左手也和右手一样> ambience [ˈæmbiəns] n 气氛，氛围=atmosphere <ambi接名词词尾，周围的是气氛> ambrosia [æmˈbrəuziə, æmˈbrəuʒə] n 希腊神话中宙斯请神仙吃的东西，美食 delicious food <周围都是玫瑰花，所以是芳香的> ambrosial [æm’brəuʒiəl] adj = delicious\ fragrant 反义词effluvial

entry.title: The second day of word 10000
entry.content: acrobat [ˈækrəbæt] n 杂技演员 acrobatics [ˌækrəˈbætɪks] n杂技 <-cs表示学科，economics经济学，acro 表示高，bat表示走，在高处走的像蝙蝠一样的人> acrophobia[,ækrə’fəubiə] n 恐高症 hydrophobia [ˌhaɪdrəˈfəubiə US -ˈfou-] n 狂犬病<恐水症> aerobatics [ˌeərəˈbætɪks ]n特技飞行 <aero-表示air,在空气中飞行> aerobics [eəˈrəubɪks US eˈrou-] n 有氧运动 -bat-还可以表示击打(to beat) abate [əˈbeit] v 缓解，减轻，减少 ​ <a表示否定，不再击打> ​ The medicine can abate your pain. rebate [ˈribeit] n退还款<打回你的卡里> baton [ˈbætɔn] n ①police 警棍 ②conductor 指挥棒 [GRE人及其使用工具]<-on作为后缀表示小，和-et-let 同，如electron 电子，“打人的小东西”→警棍> battalion [bəˈtæliən] n 军营，军队<联想battle> addle [ˈædl] v ①使困惑confuse ②表示腐坏<反复增加，不断add所以困惑了，双写加le 表示动作的反复> addle one’s brain sth addles my brain= I was confused by sth addled eggs 腐坏的鸡蛋 baffle [ˈbæfəl] v 让人迷惑 Your questions baffle me completely. <婴儿babble很让人baffle> bewilder [biˈwildə] v 令人困惑=confuse ，使惊慌失措，不知所措<be起到加强语气的作用，wild野外，惊慌失措了很wild，一个人在野外不知所措> I was bewildered by the skirts. 我让这些裙子弄花眼了（指不知道如何选择了） adept [ˈædept] a 熟练的 adapt [əˈdæpt] v适应<apt来自appropriate合适的> adopt [əˈdɔpt] v收养采纳<来自option> adopted son 养子 adoptive \foster mother养母 deft [deft] a灵巧的，熟练地 ​ adroit [əˈdrɔit] a 熟练地，灵巧的（口齿） <a表示加强，drive表示驱动，“使动起来”> inept [iˈnept] a 无能的<不熟练> inapt [inˈæpt] a 不合适的<不appropriate> adacent [əˈdʒeisənt] adj 邻近的，毗邻的，接近的<ent表示形容词后缀，ad表示加强，jac=ject=throw > ​ be ~ to reject [riˈdʒekt] v拒绝<往回扔> subjacent[sʌb’dʒeisnt] a 底层的，底下的 ejaculate [iˈdʒækjuleit] v尖叫<向外扔，声音扔出来> abject [ˈæbdʒekt] adj悲惨的，可怜的<被扔到一边>，卑鄙的 deject[di’dʒekt] v 心境低落<心情跌落下去> dejected [diˈdʒektid] adj心情低落的 conjecture [kənˈdʒektʃə] v猜测 guess <大家一起扔思想> 表“临近”： adjoin [əˈdʒɔin] vt 临近，毗邻 ​ <来自join有连接（connect）的意思> a ~s b abut [əˈbʌt] vi 临近，毗邻 <和about 同>~ on sth adjourn [əˈdʒə:n] vi延期休会 vt 中止，推迟 <ad表示加强，journ 表示day，“加强几天”→推迟> sojourn [ˈsɔdʒə:n] v 暂住 <有了住的地方所以可以去旅行> ​ When I was abroad, I ~ed in my friend’s home. diurnal [daiˈə:nəl] a白天的happening during the day <di来自day> nocturnal [nɔkˈtə:nl] a夜晚的 happening during the night <noct来自night> ~ activities defer [diˈfə:] v ①推迟，和delay相同 <fer表示carry搬，带来，“往下放”表示延迟> ②顺从于，defer to sb conference [ˈkɔnfərəns] n 会议 confer [kənˈfə:] v ①negotiate ②授予 ~ sb a degree. adulterate [əˈdʌltəreit] v 掺杂 反义：purify 提纯 成人三部曲 adultery entry.title: My first academic oral presentation
entry.content: PowerPoint MY speech draft Those bold words are significant linking words which definitely help me remember. Good morning, everyone. I am Vanora Lee, a first-year student in NUBS here at UNNC. The topic of my AOP research focuses on methods for car-sharing start-ups to reduce cash flow pressure. I’ve divided today’s talk into 3 parts. First, I’ll introduce some background information about car-sharing in China. Then I’ll move on to two of the sources I’ve already found for using in my final presentation, including general ideas and choosing reasons. At the end, I am going to show my next plan for my final presentation. So let’s begin. Do you notice this number in red? Do you know what it represents? Well, it’s the annual growth is expected for the Chinese car-sharing fleet until 2025, according to (Roland berger,2017). Although It seems like this emerging service is booming, the big danger is below the surface. Recently, many car-sharing companies went bankrupt because of cashflow pressure, such as Togo, Ezzy, Magua and so on. There is not doubt that the car-sharing as an environmentally friendly way of traveling contributes to the future sustainable development. Not only the Chinese government, but also consumers are looking forward to its wide application. So, it is definitely significant for us to consider how to reduce the cash flow pressure faced by car-sharing start-ups. That’s what my presentation will discuss. Ok，let’s move on to the first resource I’ve found in Nu search. This source clearly analyzes the urban car sharing environment in China, based on their accurate research. In this article, the latent dangers of cash flow shortage confronted by most of car-sharing start-ups are precisely demonstrated, which gives me a comprehensive understanding of this topic. Additionally, this study published in 2017 is quite recent. Also, as you can see that, it’s from a peer-reviewed journal—-‘’Advances in Transportation Studies”, which means this article is relatively reputable and reliable. In conclusion, this source is quite academic and recent. I plan to use this source in the problem analyzation since it distinctly shows the current car-sharing circumstances in China and indicates cash flow pressure as the main obstacle of those companies. Right, the second source I will be showing you today is a corporate report by Roland Berger company in 2017. This is their analysis of strategies for car-sharing start-ups to operate a successful business in China. Although it points out its popularity in Chinese market, it emphasizes that this industry is still in the initial stages. More importantly, it draws up creative and practical solutions aiming at specific problems, which inspires me a lot. Why did I choose this source? Well, initially, it is recent, and this is significant for this emerging industry’ s study. Besides, it’s reliable— Roland Berger, founded in 1967, is one of the leading global consultancies. This source is appropriate to be used in my solution part. I will be using these important central and local government policies of supporting car-sharing companies as evidence to show the feasibility of relying on assistances from the government. Now, the final part for next plan. I’ve explained to you the purpose of my presentation, showed you two of the sources I intend using, and explained why I chose them. Everything looks good since so far. But there are still some aspects needed to be improved. In the future, I plan to find visual graphs and statistics about cash flow pressure, showing the magnitude of the problem more explicitly. As for solution, some specific successful examples should be added so that this solution could be more practical. Well, I think that covers most of what I want to say today. And here is my references. If you have any questions to ask, I would be happy to answer. Thank you all so much for listening. Advantages cover all the points I want to discuss a sophisticated style Disadvantages poor time control I should be prepared sufficiently to beyond the bottom line rather than think during presentation so quick speaking speed It may be caused by my nerves. complex conception! absolutely not! learn how to express meaning clearly through simple words

entry.title: Exam Writing 1 about motivation
entry.content: Exam Writing 1 About MotivationThe topic “The level of pay is the most significant factor in influencing employee motivation.” Discuss. You must refer to Input text 1 and Input text 2 and you can use your own observations. Write at least 500 words. My essayIntroduction There is not doubt that better motivation could lead to higher work efficiency. However, the most effective approach to provide incentives is controversial. Some experts claim that salary is the most significant motivation source for all the employees. This essay will argue that although money can meet the fundamentally physical need, it is still not the most vital incentives for staff of individual differences and tremendous impacts pf intrinsic rewards. best —- the most effective is —- meet the need staff(uncountable) BP1 It has been argued that economic incentives as a form of extrinsic rewards has a dominant influence on staff’ efficiency. According to the theorist F.W. Taylor’s experiment in steel factory, the total steel yield was 3 times than before when bonuses were not given to those hard-working employees (Input text 1). It seems that the rational- economic concept of motivation is appropriate. However, Herzberg’s two factor theory disagrees with this point. He suggests that people will not work harder if they have enough money(Input text 1). For some other high-skilled employees, normal economic reward could not satisfy the demands and they always prefer other intrinsic rewards. BP2 Intrinsic motivation play a significant role in employees’ work efficiency. There are many kinds of intrinsic rewards which give workers self-esteem and happiness of helping others. For example, 12.7 million people in England volunteered once a month(Input text2). It is obvious that their purpose is not pay and they enjoy this process by being aware of their value and meaning. The happiness of helping others also can stimulate workers’ abilities. The study held by Time magazine demonstrates that students who know their calling is really helpful to people have more enthusiastic , leading to nearly 2 times profits than before(Input text 2). Happiness and self-appreciation are gained in this work experience, which encourages them to be more willing to work, even though they do not get much money. BP3 Individual differences should be noticed when considering the most effective motivation for employees, no matter intrinsic rewards or extrinsic rewards. Money is merely a physiological need, which is at the bottom of the Maslow’s hierarchy of needs(Input text 1). There are many other higher levels in this hierarchy, which is suitable to used to explain different status of employees’ motivation prefer. For example, the significant difference between workers in factory and designers in Apple is that those workers need to follow specific rules strictly in case of being discharged. However, for designers in Apple, instead of concerning regulations and salaries, they prefer to chase esteem and self- actualization(Input text 1). Therefore, different status of employees may have different objectives, resulting in various motivation source. Conclusion Money indeed has strong effects on employees’ motivation, particularly for those some low- paid or unskilled employees. However, the argument that salary is the most important factor can not perfectly applied to all the employees since there are individual differences and important effects of other intrinsic rewards. The most efficient method to provide best motivation for single employee is to consider intrinsic and extrinsic rewards at the same time, noticing individual differences. Social needs and sense of achievement are more effective tools of motivation. entry.title: Silence of the lambs
entry.content: Silence of the lambsThe original ending **In the original ending, Lecter is cutting orange segments with a small paring knife, while he speaks to Clarice. As he hangs up the phone, the camera shot widens. We discover that he is at a desk in a book lined office. There is the body of a bodyguard on the floor, and then we see Lecter is not alone. Chilton is trussed up in a chair across from him, the same method of restraints the doctor used on Lecter earlier in the movie. Lecter rises, slowly, a dreamy gleam in his eye, as he approaches his terrified victim, paring knife in hand. “Shall we begin?” **

entry.title: The book thief movie review
entry.content: The book thief movie review This film is adapted from the 2005 young-adult bestseller by Australian writer Markus Zusak. The leading character is —Liesel, a young girl in 1930s Germany who is left to kindly but harassed foster parents Hans and Rosa by her fugitive Communist mother. The brutal reality of the Holocaust is not dwelt upon. It is this trio’s courage and victimhood that take center-stage.** Liesel is forced to join the Hitler Youth, but is secretly disgusted by the Nazis’ book-burning displays and conceives a love of literature by “borrowing” books from the Mayor’s wife. And as war breaks out, she is taught to love writing by Max, the Jew that her foster parents are hiding in the cellar, and whose deferential friendship and gratitude are the guarantee of their good-Germanness. It is true that this lite-historical tosh has absolutely nothing in common with the power of Steven Spielberg’s Schindler’s List. It’s a worryingly lenient and obtuse approach to history and historical evil, which are smothered in feelgood tragi-sentimental slush. “The Book Thief” has its moments of brilliance, thanks in large part to an adept cast. But the movie about a girl adopted by a German couple during World War II also crystallizes the perils of book adaptations. Based on a bestselling novel, the movie tries heartily to contain writer Markus Zusak’s myriad plot points, but the result is a rushed conclusion, which tempers the intended tear-jerking climax. The sticky-fingered title character is Liesel. With bouncy blond hair and big, sad eyes, actress Sophie Nélisse utterly embodies the character of a girl given up for adoption shortly after her brother dies. When Liesel’s on-the-run Communist mother can no longer care for her, she’s taken in by Hans (Geoffrey Rush) and Rosa (Emily Watson). The child immediately bonds with her new father, a smiling accordion player who calls Liesel “your majesty.” Rosa is more standoffish and looks constantly for excuses to yell. (She finds many.) Despite her tendency to pick up lost books, Liesel can’t read or write, and that momentarily makes her a punch line at school. One bully learns quickly, though, that although Liesel can’t spell, she can fight, and that’s just the first hint of her tenacious personality. After Hans teaches her to read, Liesel’s world begins to expand, both through stories from books she sneakily “borrows” and in a reality that’s informed by an oppressive regime. In this small German village, she finds reasons to be optimistic thanks to a friendship with another youngster, Rudy (Nico Liersch), but she also comes to understand the saddest repercussion of Third Reich rule after a man named Max comes to the family’s door one night. The son of Hans’s old friend, Max is Jewish and on the run, and he ends up hiding in the family’s basement. There is plenty here to create both an emotional payoff and a healthy dose of suspense. But director Brian Percival’s film squanders the opportunities by squeezing a number of other subplots into the two-hour run time. These threads have the space to breathe and evolve in a novel, but when it comes to the film, less would have been more. That being said, “The Book Thief” has its pleasures. Along with a memorable performance from Nélisse, Rush and Watson prove their impressive range. Despite the film’s dark themes, there are a number of scenes of gentle comedy, and those come mostly thanks to Rush’s and Watson’s facial expressions and delivery. Ben Schnetzer, who plays Max, hasn’t acted in many films, but his performance is indelible as an older brother figure trying to protect his young friend from the sad realities of the day. From the pristinely shot scenes of a train chugging through a snowy landscape that open the film, “The Book Thief” has a sleekness to it. That feeling is mirrored in a plot that feels whitewashed in some ways. For example, Rosa discusses cutting back on meals now that the family has to provide for its refu­gee, but there aren’t depictions of hunger or suffering. Just as Max tempers the reality for Liesel, the movie does the same for its viewers. That ensures a PG-13 rating and a broader audience, of course. But when the delivery is blunted, the audience’s emotions will tend to follow suit. ​ The brown Chocolate color is the death’s favorite.

entry.title: Everyday RC——Ecoefficiency
entry.content: #Everyday RC——Ecoefficiency Ecoefficiency (measures to minimize environmental impact through thereduction or elimination of waste from production processes) has becomea goal for companies worldwide, with many realizing significant costsavings from such innovations. Peter Senge and Goran Carstedt see thisdevelopment as laudable but suggest that simply adopting ecoefficiencyinnovations could actually worsen environmental stresses in the future.Such innovations reduce production waste but do not alter the number ofproducts manufactured nor the waste generated from their use anddiscard; indeed, most companies invest in ecoefficiency improvements inorder to increase profits and growth. Moreover, there is no guaranteethat increased economic growth from ecoefficiency will come in similarlyecoefficient ways, since in today’s global markets, greater profits maybe turned into investment capital that could easily be reinvested inold-style eco-inefficient industries. Even a vastly more ecoefficientindustrial system could, were it to grow much larger, generate moretotal waste and destroy more habitat and species than would a smaller,less ecoefficient economy. Senge and Carstedt argue that to preserve theglobal environment and sustain economic growth, businesses must developa new systemic approach that reduces total material use and totalaccumulated waste. Focusing exclusively on ecoefficiency, which offers acompelling business case according to established thinking, may distract companies from pursuing radically different products andbusiness models. Analyzation of the whole structureGeneral Background introduction TC VIEW(positive and negative) 3 negative consequences conclusion(positive and negative) Specific Ecoefficiency (measures to minimize environmental impact through thereduction or elimination of waste from production processes) has becomea goal for companies worldwide, with many realizing significant costsavings from such innovations. main function : BS PS: bankrupt in BS is important Peter Senge and Goran Carstedt see this development as laudable but suggest that simply adopting ecoefficiencyinnovations could actually worsen environmental stresses in the future. main function : main view(S&&C) of ecoefficiency PS: Remember the family name Include both positive and negative view “But” indicates that “negative” aspect is more important Such innovations reduce production waste but do not alter the number ofproducts manufactured nor the waste generated from their use anddiscard; indeed, most companies invest in ecoefficiency improvements inorder to increase profits and growth. main function : explain the view (negative)[1] PS : “Such” shows its connection with the previous sentence Before “but” : positive, After “but” : negative indeed : link with smooth transition Moreover, there is no guaranteethat increased economic growth from ecoefficiency will come in similarlyecoefficient ways, since in today’s global markets, greater profits maybe turned into investment capital that could easily be reinvested inold-style eco-inefficient industries. main function : explain the view (negative)[2] PS : Moreover : link with smooth transition Even a vastly more ecoefficientindustrial system could, were it to grow much larger, generate moretotal waste and destroy more habitat and species than would a smaller,less ecoefficient economy. main function : explain the view (negative)[3] PS : Even : link with smooth transition “more, than” : notice comparison Senge and Carstedt argue that to preserve theglobal environment and sustain economic growth, businesses must developa new systemic approach that reduces total material use and totalaccumulated waste. main function : attitude again and the future PS : notice “new” Focusing exclusively on ecoefficiency, which offers acompelling business case according to established thinking, maydistract companies from pursuing radically different products andbusiness models. main function : the mixture view again PS : “compelling”(P) and “distract”(G)—same as TC Vocabularies （https://www.vocabulary.com/dictionary/laudable） （https://www.vocabulary.com/dictionary/exclusively）
